name: Meteorite Landings
title: Meteorite Landings

api_list.name: /year
api_list.description: The 'year' endpoint in the MeteoriteLandings API retrieves an of strings listing all the available values for the 'year' field. This field represents the year in which meteorite landings were recorded. By accessing this endpoint, users can explore and obtain a comprehensive overview of the different years for which meteorite landings data is available. This information can be valuable for researchers, scientists, or enthusiasts interested in studying meteorite activities over time. The array of strings obtained from this endpoint will consist of unique values corresponding to the years when meteorite landings were documented. By analyzing this data, users can gain insights into trends, patterns, or variations in meteorite occurrences based on different years, facilitating further analysis and exploration of meteorite phenomena.

api_list.name: /recclass
api_list.description: The 'recclass' endpoint in the 'MeteoriteLandings' API provides a useful array of strings that represent the possible values for the field 'recclass'. This field specifies the classification of meteorites based on their composition and characteristics. By accessing this endpoint, you can obtain an extensive list of different meteorite classifications, such as iron meteorites (e.g., IAB, IID), stony meteorites (e.g., H, L, LL), carbonaceous chondrites (e.g., CI1, CM2), and various other classifications like enstatite chondrites (e.g., EH3), achondrites (e.g., AC3, E6), and lunar meteorites (e.g., LUN). Understanding the 'recclass' values can provide valuable insights into the types of meteorites observed and help researchers categorize them accordingly. Whether you are an enthusiast or a scientist, this endpoint allows you to explore the vast array of meteorite classifications available, expanding your knowledge about these fascinating extraterrestrial objects.

api_list.name: /geolocation
api_list.description: The 'geolocation' endpoint of the 'MeteoriteLandings' API provides an array of possible values for the field 'geolocation'. Geolocation refers to the specific coordinates on the Earth's surface where meteorites have landed. The endpoint returns an array of strings, each representing a unique geolocation in a specific format like (latitude, longitude). By accessing this endpoint, you can obtain a comprehensive list of different geolocation values where meteorites have been found across the globe. These geolocation coordinates help scientists and enthusiasts to study the distribution and impact patterns of meteorites on our planet. The 'geolocation' endpoint is useful for researchers, scientists, and anyone interested in understanding the meteorite landings across the Earth. This data can contribute to studies on meteorite origins, their trajectories, and the potential geological and climatic implications associated with such events.

api_list.name: /reclat
api_list.description: The 'reclat' endpoint from the 'MeteoriteLandings' API provides an array of strings that represent the possible latitude values for recorded meteorite landings. Latitude is a geographic coordinate that indicates the position of a location on Earth, measured in degrees north or south of the equator. This endpoint allows users to access a range of latitude values for meteorite landings, providing valuable information about the distribution of meteorites across different geographic locations. By analyzing this information, scientists and researchers can gain insights into patterns or trends related to meteorite impacts on Earth. The array of strings returned by this endpoint may include various latitude values such as positive or negative decimal numbers. These values correspond to the exact coordinates or locations where meteorites have been recorded to have fallen. Utilizing this endpoint, developers and data enthusiasts can explore and analyze meteorite landing data based on latitude, enabling them to perform geospatial analyses or create visualizations related to meteorite impacts around the world.

api_list.name: /fall
api_list.description: The 'fall' endpoint in the 'MeteoriteLandings' API returns a collection of different values for the field 'fall'. This field indicates whether a meteorite was found or witnessed falling from the sky. The endpoint provides an array of strings that represent possible values for 'fall', each describing the circumstances of a meteorite's discovery. By using this endpoint, you can retrieve a list of diverse terms that classify various meteorites' occurrences, excluding the specific example values mentioned earlier. These values help differentiate between meteorites that were spotted directly as they fell and those that were discovered afterward. By accessing the 'fall' endpoint, users can gain insights into the ways meteorites have been identified, categorized, and studied by scientists and enthusiasts worldwide.

api_list.name: /id
api_list.description: The 'id' endpoint in the MeteoriteLandings API provides an array of unique identification numbers associated with meteorite landings. Each meteorite that has been documented and recorded in this database is assigned a specific 'id' that distinguishes it from others. These identification numbers are used to track and refer to individual meteorite records within the API.When you make a request to this endpoint, you will receive a list of strings representing the possible values for the 'id' field. These values are typically numeric and can range from relatively small numbers to larger ones, such as the examples mentioned (38708, 53047, 18017). Each 'id' corresponds to a specific entry in the MeteoriteLandings API dataset, allowing users to access detailed information about individual meteorite instances by using the respective 'id'.By utilizing the 'id' endpoint, users can easily identify and retrieve specific meteorite records based on their unique identification numbers, facilitating further exploration and analysis of meteorite landings.

api_list.name: /nametype
api_list.description: The 'nametype' endpoint from the 'MeteoriteLandings' provides a collection of different values that can appear in the 'nametype' field. This field refers to the type of name given to a meteorite. The endpoint returns an array of strings, which are the possible values that can be assigned to the 'nametype' field.By accessing this endpoint, users can gain insights into the various types of names that meteorites can be categorized under. These names can range from specific scientific designations to more general classifications. The 'nametype' field helps in identifying whether a meteorite has been officially named or categorized based on certain criteria.By exploring this endpoint, researchers, enthusiasts, or anyone interested in meteorites can obtain a comprehensive list of the different nametypes associated with meteorites. This information can facilitate studies, analyses, or simply satisfy curiosities about the range of nametypes used to describe these extraterrestrial entities.

api_list.name: /reclong
api_list.description: The endpoint 'reclong' from the API 'MeteoriteLandings' provides valuable information about longitudes associated with meteorite landings. A longitude is a geographic coordinate that helps us pinpoint a location on the Earth's surface eastward or westward from the Prime Meridian. This endpoint returns an array of strings representing the possible values for the 'reclong' field.These string values, excluding the examples mentioned, can be used to discover the specific longitudes of meteorite landings recorded in the API's dataset. By accessing this endpoint, users can obtain a comprehensive list of longitude coordinates related to meteorite impact locations. The 'reclong' field assists scientists, researchers, and enthusiasts in identifying geographical trends or patterns associated with meteorite landings across different regions of the world. This information can contribute to understanding meteorite impact patterns, studying their origins, and assessing potential risks they may pose to our planet.

api_list.name: /dataListIndex
api_list.description: The endpoint 'dataListIndex' from the API 'MeteoriteLandings' provides a user-friendly way to retrieve an array of possible values for the field 'dataListIndex'. This field represents a unique identification number associated with meteorite landings recorded in the database. Each value in the array represents a different meteorite landing event. These values play an important role in organizing and categorizing meteorite data.By accessing this endpoint, you can obtain an array of strings consisting of these dataListIndex values. These strings are typically numeric, like the examples provided (44409, 8646, 30982), but can also contain other characters depending on the specific implementation. These values can then be used to query specific meteorite landing records or to perform further analysis on the data.This endpoint allows users to explore and understand the vast dataset of meteorite landings by providing a comprehensive list of all possible dataListIndex values.

api_list.name: /records
api_list.description: The 'records' endpoint is a powerful feature of the API 'MeteoriteLandings' that allows users to retrieve specific information in the form of an array of objects. This endpoint acts as the main gateway to access the valuable data associated with meteorite landings. By utilizing various query parameters, users can tailor their search to fetch only the rows of data that are particularly relevant to their needs.When making a request to the 'records' endpoint, the API returns an array of objects encapsulating the desired information. Each object within the array represents a specific record related to meteorite landings. These records furnish a range of details such as the name of the meteorite, its mass, its composition, the year it was observed, and the geographical location where it was discovered.By leveraging the 'records' endpoint, users have the opportunity to explore and analyze the vast dataset of meteorite landings based on their specific criteria. Whether it's for research, educational purposes, or sheer curiosity, this rich array of objects allows users to uncover and glean insightful knowledge about meteorites and their terrestrial encounters.

api_list.name: /massG
api_list.description: The 'massG' endpoint in the 'MeteoriteLandings' API provides a list of various values for the field 'massG', which represents the mass of meteorites that have landed on Earth. It returns an array of strings containing different numerical values representing the mass of meteorites.This endpoint allows users to retrieve a range of possible mass values for meteorites, helping researchers, enthusiasts, and curious individuals explore the diverse sizes and weights of these extraterrestrial objects. The 'massG' field provides information about the weight of a meteorite, measured in grams. By accessing this endpoint, users can gain insights into the range of masses recorded, from lighter meteorites to much heavier ones. This information is valuable for scientists studying meteorites' composition, impact patterns, and potential hazards they may pose. Exploring the 'massG' endpoint enables users to better comprehend the vast array of weights exhibited by these fascinating cosmic visitors.

api_list.name: /name
api_list.description: The 'name' endpoint from the 'MeteoriteLandings' API is a useful feature that provides an array of strings containing various names of meteorites that have landed on Earth. It allows users to access a comprehensive list of meteorite names, providing valuable information about each unique meteorite that has been discovered and documented. Each string in the array represents a different meteorite name, which may be intriguing and distinctive. By utilizing this endpoint, users can explore a wide range of meteorite names, allowing for research, analysis, and curiosity. The names can highlight factors such as the location of discovery, numerical codes, or even specific names assigned by researchers.For instance, while the endpoint does not provide specific example values (such as 'Yamato 982086 Dominion Range 08201 O'Malley 001'), it does empower users to discover similar captivating and diverse meteorite names. This endpoint within the 'MeteoriteLandings' API allows users to delve into the intriguing world of meteorites, fostering a better understanding of these celestial objects that have landed on our planet.
